prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: G5
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will use band 4 to search for detections in HCN(2-1), HCO+(2-1), HOC+(2-1) and HNC(2-1).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our primary goal is to detect HCN(2-1) line emission for 10 targets. The same spectral setups also cover the wavelength ranges for HCO+(2-1), HNC(2-1) and HOC+(2-1). If these lines are strong, we can detect them as well. HCN(2-1) and HCO+(2-1) should be of the same order of magnitude. This proposal is a detection experiement, and our primary goal is first detecting these faint HCN(2-1) emission lines from the distant galaxies. We target a single HCN(2-1) transition, using Band 4 and Band 3, depending on the redshift.
Our targets are selected to be ULIRGs at z ~ 0.2 - 0.8 with strong CO(1-0) or CO(2-1) emission already detected by IRAM (Combes et al. 2011, 2013). Based on these CO(1-0) or CO(2-1) fluxes, we estimated the expected HCN line fluxes. We assumed the following line ratios for our 10 ULIRGs, with HCN(1-0)/CO(1-0)=HCN(2-1)/CO(2-1)=0.1.
As listed in Table 1 in the proposal, the expected HCN fluxes ranges from 0.63-5.7mJy. These estimated fluxes set the required rms sensitivies we need for each target. To achieve the significant detections, we require a 50km/s velocity resolution, and a minimum SNR of 5 per velocity resolution element for the first 7 targets. With the FWHM of 250km/s for the lines, we expect to have the total line detection SNR in the range of (10-25). The remaining 3 targets are at higher redshifts, we aim to first detect HCN(2-1) emission line over a 250km/s velovity resolution with a SNR > (4.5-6.5).
We will use four spectral windows, with two spectral windows covering HCN(2-1), HCO+(2-1), HOC+(2-1) and HNC(2-1) lines, and other two windows covering continuum. We want to have the same angular resolution for all targets at 1 arcseconds. The dense molecular gas regions are expected to be unresolved, point sources.
We will observe in dual polarization mode with 1.875 GHz total bandwidth per baseband, and pre-smoothed velocity resolution of 3.9 MHz (~ 8.6 km/s) for Band 4 and 3. The final smoothing resolution is 50km/s for all sources except last three sources which are at higher redshifts. We expect that the spatial extent of dense molecular gas in our targets are too small to be filtered out. We therefore do not require ACA observations.
In summary, we require 7.73 hours for 10 targets, including all overhead and calibrations.

We will observe in dual polarization mode with 1.875GHz bandwidth per baseband, and pre-smoothed velocity resolution of 3.9MHz (~8.6km/s) for Band 4. The final smoothed resolution is 50km/s for all sources. We expect that the spatial extent of dense molecular gas in our galaxies is too small to be filtered out. We therefore do not require ACA observations.
Our science goal is to detect these faint HCN lines, we do not need to spatially resolve the dense molecular gas regions. We request 1arcseconds resolution for all targets.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: G12
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will use band 4 to search for detections in HCN(2-1), HCO+(2-1), HOC+(2-1) and HNC(2-1).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We aim to detect HCN (2-1) and HCO+(2-1) lines simultaneously for 10 targets (and also 13CO(4-3) for two sources).These two lines should be of the same order of magnitude. Our targets are at redshifts 0.2 - 0.8, which limit our observations of HCN to (2-1) transition observed in Band 4 or Band 3, as shown in Table 1.
Our targets are selected to be ULIRGs at z ~ 0.2 - 0.8 with strong CO(1-0) or CO(2-1) emission already detected by IRAM (Combes et al. 2011, 2013). Based on these CO(1-0) or CO(2-1) fluxes, we estimated the expected HCN line fluxes. We assumed the following ratios for our 10 ULIRGs, with HCN(1-0)/CO(1-0)=HCN(2-1)/CO(2-1)=0.1.
As listed in Table 1 in the proposal, the expected HCN fluxes ranges from 0.63-5.7mJy. These estimated fluxes set the required rms sensitivies we need for each target. To achieve the significant detections, we require a 50km/s velocity resolution for the first 7 sources at lower redshifts, and a minimum SNR of 5 per velocity resolution element. With the FWHM of 250km/s for the lines, we should expect to have the total line detection SNR ~ (5-11)*sqrt(5) ~ (10-25). For the remaining 3 sources at higher redshifts, we will aim for detections with SNR ~ (4.5-6.5) over the total 250km/s velocity width.
We will use four spectral windows, with two spectral windows covering HCN and HCO+ lines, and other two windows covering continuum. We want to have the same angular resolution for all targets, thus we adapt the configuration accroding to the redshifts to achieve physical size of 3kpc synthesized beam. This means that we use angular resolution 1 arcseconds for targets at z~0.2-0.4, and 0.4 arcseconds for targets at z~0.6-0.8. We expect that dense molecular gas probed by HCN will be quite concentrated within 3\,kpc, so that the observation is a detection experiment. For three sources at z~ 0.6-0.8, Band 6 continuum observations will probe the cold dust emission at the rest-frame 500-600micron. With our specially designed 0.4arcsecond resolution, we should be able to resolve the far-IR emission region. Measurements on sizes and surface brightness of far-IR emission would be in complimentary with the measurement of dense molecular gas.
We will observe in dual polarization mode with 1.875 GHz total bandwidth per baseband, and pre-smoothed velocity resolution of 3.9 MHz (~ 8.6 km/s) for Band 4 and 7.8 MHz(~10 Km/s) for Band 6(FDM). The final smoothing resolution is 50km/s for all sources. We expect that the spatial extent of dense molecular gas in our targets are too small to be filtered out. We therefore do not require ACA observations.
In summary, we require 7.73 hours for 10 targets, including all overhead and calibrations.

We request a spectral resolution of 4MHz, corresponding to 8km/s at 2mm. We will smooth in velocity to a resolution of 50km/s to obtain a higher SNR. This is sufficient to resolve the shape of the HCN line, having an expected width of 250km/s. The remainder of the spectral windows are set to achieve a maxmimum bandwidth of 1875MHz in order to observe the millimeter continuum. With the observing time needed for the primary line observations, this will allow us to detect continuum emission if very cold dust is present.
Our galaxies are at redshift 0.2-0.8, all targets are point sources for the requested observations. Thus we request all observations are done with angular resolution of 1arcseconds.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: G15
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: One pointing for HCN(2-1) and HCO+(2-1)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We aim to detect HCN and HCO+ lines simultaneously for 10 targets. These two lines should be of the same order of magnitude. Our targets are at redshifts 0.2 - 0.8, which allow us to observe HCN(2-1) in Band 4 or Band 3 depending on the redshift. See Table 1 for details.
Our targets are selected to be ULIRGs at z ~ 0.2 - 0.8 with strong CO(1-0) or CO(2-1) emission already detected by IRAM (Combes et al. 2011, 2013). Based on these CO(1-0) or CO(2-1) fluxes, we estimated the expected HCN line fluxes. We assumed the following ratios for our 10 ULIRGs, with HCN(1-0)/CO(1-0)=HCN(2-1)/CO(2-1)=0.1.
As listed in Table 1 in the proposal, the expected HCN fluxes ranges from 0.63-5.7mJy. These estimated fluxes set the required rms sensitivies we need for each target. To achieve the significant detections, we require a 50km/s velocity resolution, and a minimum SNR of 5 per velocity resolution element. With the FWHM of 250km/s for the lines, we should expect to have the total line detection SNRs ~ (5-11.4)*sqrt(5) ~ (10-25).
We will use four spectral windows, with two spectral windows covering HCN and HCO+ lines, and other two windows covering continuum. We want to have the same angular resolution for all targets, thus we adapt the configuration accroding to the redshifts to achieve physical size of 3kpc synthesized beam. This means that we use angular resolution 1 arcseconds for targets at z~0.2-0.4, and 0.4 arcseconds for targets at z~0.6-0.8. We expect that dense molecular gas probed by HCN will be quite concentrated within 3\,kpc, so that the observation is a detection experiment. For three sources at z~ 0.6-0.8, Band 6 continuum observations will probe the cold dust emission at the rest-frame 500-600micron. With our specially designed 0.4arcsecond resolution, we should be able to resolve the far-IR emission region. Measurements on sizes and surface brightness of far-IR emission would be in complimentary with the measurement of dense molecular gas.
We will observe in dual polarization mode with 1.875 GHz total bandwidth per baseband, and pre-smoothed velocity resolution of 3.9 MHz (~ 8.6 km/s) for Band 4 and Band 3. The final smoothing resolution is 50km/s for the first 7 sources, and the remaining 3 sources are at higher redshifts, and we aim to first detect HCN(2-1) lines over 250km/s velocity widths. We expect that the spatial extent of dense molecular gas in our targets are too small to be filtered out. We therefore do not require ACA observations.
In summary, we require 7.73 hours for 10 targets, including all overhead and calibrations.

We will observe in duel polarization mode with 1.875GHz total bandwidth per baseband. We request a spectral resolution of 4MHz, corresponding to 8km/s at 2mm. We will smooth in velocity to a resolution of 50km/s to obtain a higher SNR. This is sufficient to resolve the shape of the HCN(2-1) line, having an expected line width of 250km/s. The remainder of the spectral windows are set to achieve a maximum bandwidth of 1875MHz in order to observe the millimeter continuum. With the observing time needed for the primary line observations, we may detect mm continuum if very cold dust is present.

All of our targets are point sources. The dense molecular gas regions are too compact to be spatially resolved in Band 4 and 3. This program aims to first detect the line emission. Thus we request all observations done with angular resolution of 1 arcsecond.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: G17
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 4 for HCN(2-1) and HCO+(2-1) + continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:

This proposal is a detection experiement, and our primary goal is first detecting these faint HCN(2-1) emission lines from the distant galaxies. We target a single HCN(2-1) transition, using Band 4 and Band 3, depending on the redshift.
Our targets are selected to be ULIRGs at z ~ 0.2 - 0.8 with strong CO(1-0) or CO(2-1) emission already detected by IRAM (Combes et al. 2011, 2013). With the FWHM of 250km/s for the lines, we expect to have the total line detection SNR in the range of (10-25). The remaining 3 targets are at higher redshifts, we aim to first detect HCN(2-1) emission line over a 250km/s velovity resolution with a SNR > (4.5-6.5).
We will use four spectral windows, with two spectral windows covering HCN(2-1), HCO+(2-1), HOC+(2-1) and HNC(2-1) lines, and other two windows covering continuum. We want to have the same angular resolution for all targets at 1 arcseconds. The dense molecular gas regions are expected to be unresolved, point sources.
We will observe in dual polarization mode with 1.875 GHz total bandwidth per baseband, and pre-smoothed velocity resolution of 3.9 MHz (~ 8.6 km/s) for Band 4 and 3. The final smoothing resolution is 50km/s for all sources except last three sources which are at higher redshifts. We expect that the spatial extent of dense molecular gas in our targets are too small to be filtered out. We therefore do not require ACA observations.
In summary, we require 7.73 hours for 10 targets, including all overhead and calibrations.

We will observe in duel polarization mode with 1.875GHz total bandwidth per baseband. We request a spectral resolution of 4MHz, corresponding to 8km/s at 2mm. We will smooth in velocity to a resolution of 50km/s to obtain a higher SNR. This is sufficient to resolve the shape of the HCN(2-1) line, having an expected line width of 250km/s. The remainder of the spectral windows are set to achieve a maximum bandwidth of 1875MHz in order to observe the millimeter continuum. With the observing time needed for the primary line observations, we may detect mm continuum if very cold dust is present.
Our science goal is to detect these faint HCN lines, we do not need to spatially resolve the dense molecular gas regions. We request 1arcseconds resolution for all targets.

Based on these CO(1-0) or CO(2-1) fluxes, we estimated the expected HCN line fluxes. We assumed the following line ratios for our 10 ULIRGs, with HCN(1-0)/CO(1-0)=HCN(2-1)/CO(2-1)=0.1.
As listed in Table 1 in the proposal, the expected HCN fluxes ranges from 0.63-5.7mJy. These estimated fluxes set the required rms sensitivies we need for each target. To achieve the significant detections, we require a 50km/s velocity resolution, and a minimum SNR of 5 per velocity resolution element for the first 7 targets. With the FWHM of 250km/s for the lines, we expect to have the total line detection SNR in the range of (10-25). The remaining 3 targets are at higher redshifts, we aim to first detect HCN(2-1) emission line over a 250km/s velovity resolution with a SNR > (4.5-6.5).
We will use four spectral windows, with two spectral windows covering HCN(2-1), HCO+(2-1), HOC+(2-1) and HNC(2-1) lines, and other two windows covering continuum. We want to have the same angular resolution for all targets at 1 arcseconds. The dense molecular gas regions are expected to be unresolved, point sources.
We will observe in dual polarization mode with 1.875 GHz total bandwidth per baseband, and pre-smoothed velocity resolution of 3.9 MHz (~ 8.6 km/s) for Band 4 and 3. The final smoothing resolution is 50km/s for all sources except last three sources which are at higher redshifts. We expect that the spatial extent of dense molecular gas in our targets are too small to be filtered out. We therefore do not require ACA observations.
In summary, we require 7.73 hours for 10 targets, including all overhead and calibrations.

We will observe in duel polarization mode with 1.875GHz total bandwidth per baseband. We request a spectral resolution of 4MHz, corresponding to 8km/s at 2mm. We will smooth in velocity to a resolution of 50km/s to obtain a higher SNR. This is sufficient to resolve the shape of the HCN(2-1) line, having an expected line width of 250km/s. The remainder of the spectral windows are set to achieve a maximum bandwidth of 1875MHz in order to observe the millimeter continuum. With the observing time needed for the primary line observations, we may detect mm continuum if very cold dust is present.
Our science goal is to detect these faint HCN lines, we do not need to spatially resolve the dense molecular gas regions. We request 1arcseconds resolution for all targets.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Progess on dense molecular gas at high-z has been limited due to intrinsic weakness of HCN emission and low sensitivities of none-ALMA facilities. The most significant finding from studies of local galaxies is that star formation efficiency (SFE(dense)=L(FIR)/L(HCN)) is shown to be constant across scales from giant molecular clouds to nearby normal star forming galaxies. This result holds for both HCN(1-0) and higher J transitions. These studies have also revealed tantalizing evidence, suggesting that SFE(dense) and dense gas fraction (L(HCN)/L(CO)) may evolve as a function of both IR luminosity and redshift. However, the total number of existing high-z HCN detections is 5, all z>2 sources with AGNs. Do high-z and more luminous galaxies have higher fraction of dense molecular gas? Are they forming stars more efficiently in comparison with z~0? Answers to both questions will have profound implications to our understanding of galaxy evolution. We request 7.73hrs to detect HCN(2-1) for 10 ULIRGs at z~0.2-0.8 with high CO(1-0) or (2-1) fluxes. This z-range is chosen so that HCN(2-1), with well defined excitation mechanism than that of high J lines, is still accessible from ALMA.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Infrared Processing and Analysis Center (IPAC), California Institute of Technology

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Observatorio de Madrid, Observatorio Astronomico Nacional
